STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
March 13, 2025
Natasha Doan-Motsinger
Our House- Mosaic
111 S. Wallace Blvd.
Ypsilanti, MI, 48197-4644
Re: License #: CB810406448
Dear Ms. Doan-Motsinger:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
3/11/25. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective action
plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and
must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (616) 204-6992.
Sincerely,
Heather Reilly, Licensing Consultant
enclosure

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the following:
CPA Rule 400.12212 Personnel records
(2) The personnel record must contain all the following
information before employment may occur:
(d) Three references obtained from persons who are
unrelated to the staff person.
Two of nine employee files did not have references completed as required.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
3/14/23 INTERIM, CAP approved 4/18/23
1 /17/24 RENEWAL, CAP approved 2/13/24
CPA Rule 400.12212 Personnel records
(2) The personnel record must contain all the following
information before employment may occur:
(e) A record of any convictions other than minor traffic
violations from either of the following: (ii) An entity
accessing either Michigan state police records or
equivalent state or Canadian provincial law enforcement
agency where the person usually resides.
Two of nine employee files did not have clearances completed prior to hire.
CPA Rule 400.12212 Personnel records
2

(2) The personnel record must contain all the following
information before employment may occur:
(h) Documentation from the department that the person
has not been named in a central registry case as the
perpetrator of child abuse or neglect in Michigan or in
any state where the person lived in the 5 years
preceding hire.
Two of nine employee files did not have central registry checks completed prior to
hire. One of which was an out of state check.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
1 /17/24 RENEWAL, CAP approved 2/13/24
CPA Rule 400.12212 Personnel records
(3) The personnel record must contain both of the
following:
(b) A copy of the job description for the staff member's
current position.
Three of nine employee files did not have a job description on file.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
3/14/23 INTERIM, CAP approved 4/18/23
1/17/24 RENEWAL, CAP approved 2/13/24
CPA Rule 400.12212 Personnel records
(4) An agency shall maintain an orientation and training
record for staff members.
Four of nine employee files did not have orientation documented in their file.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
1/17/24 RENEWAL, CAP approved 2/13/24
CPA Rule 400.12510 Independent living agreement
(2) The agreement must be signed and dated by the
youth and the social service worker. The agreement
must be reviewed with the youth at least once every 90
calendar days and a copy provided to the youth.
One of one youth files did not have a signed independent living agreement.
3

REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED

CPA Rule 400.12511 Termination
(1) When an agency terminates its independent living
services for a youth, the agency shall document all the
following information in the case record within 30
calendar days of termination of its services:
(a) The reason for the termination.
Two of two closed files did not have the required documentation.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
3/14/23 INTERIM, CAP approved 4/18/23
CPA Rule 400.12511 Termination
(1) When an agency terminates its independent living
services for a youth, the agency shall document all the
following information in the case record within 30
calendar days of termination of its services:
(b) The youth's new location.
Two of two closed files did not have the required documentation.

CPA Rule 400.12511 Termination
(1) When an agency terminates its independent living
services for a youth, the agency shall document all the
following information in the case record within 30
calendar days of termination of its services:
(c) A summary of the services provided during care and
the needs that remain to be met.

REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
3/14/23 INTERIM, CAP approved 4/18/23
CPA Rule 400.12511 Termination
4

(1) When an agency terminates its independent living
services for a youth, the agency shall document all the
following information in the case record within 30
calendar days of termination of its services:
(d) Provision for any follow-up services.
Two of two closed files did not have the required documentation.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED

CPA Rule 400.12511 Termination
(2) An agency shall ensure and document that each
youth who ends independent living is provided with all
the following:
(a) Basic information about health, housing, counseling
and mental health services, and emergency resources.
Two of two closed files did not have the required documentation.
CPA Rule 400.12511 Termination
(2) An agency shall ensure and document that each
youth who ends independent living is provided with all
the following:
(b) A birth certificate.
Two of two closed files did not have the required documentation.
CPA Rule 400.12511 Termination
(2) An agency shall ensure and document that each
youth who ends independent living is provided with all

Two of two closed files did not have the required documentation.
CPA Rule 400.12511 Termination
(2) An agency shall ensure and document that each
youth who ends independent living is provided with all
the following:
5

(d) The youth's funds and personal property.
Two of two closed files did not have the required documentation.
CPA Rule 400.12203 Financial stability
(1) An agency shall demonstrate sufficient financing, on
an ongoing basis, to ensure the agency is carrying out its
programs and meeting the requirements for licensing. A
plan of financing must include all the following:
(e) an audit of all financial accounts conducted annually
by an independent certified public accountant not
administratively related to the agency. A copy of the
audit shall be available to the department upon request.
The agency did not have an annual financial audit available for review.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• Performance evaluations: The agency was reminded that performance
evaluations must be completed for all staff, even if the agency does not
have youth placed at that time.
• Policy, procedure, and program statements for IL youth: The agency was
advised that youth must sign an acknowledgement that staff reviewed this
information and provided a copy to the youth.
• Chief Administrator Assessment: The agency was provided with guidance
regarding the information required in the assessment.
• Annual financial audit: A conversation occurred with the chief
administrator regarding the requirement to have a financial audit by a
certified public accountant completed annually. Regardless of a waiver or
exception from MDHHS contracts.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following area:
• Out of state clearances for staff: The agency was informed that if an out of
state clearances is projected to take an extended amount of time, the
agency may request a variance to hire the employee and complete
training and new hire actions with the staff, while awaiting the clearance.
VI. EVALUATION OF PERIOD UNDER REVIEW
Maltreatment in Care
6

There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during the licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted one acceptable corrective action plan (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with the CAP is as follows:
The agency renewal inspection was completed on 1/17/24 with a CAP approved
on 2/13/24. The agency was cited for seven violations, four of which were
repeated this year. In the 2023 interim review, six violations were found. Four of
which were repeated this year. This 2025 report reflects seven repeat violations
from 2023 as rule 511 (1) was separated out this year, whereas it was combined
in the 2023 report. The agency reported having a difficult year, as in March 2024
the independent living program closed. Youth were discharged from the program
and staff were released from employment. Over several months, the chief
administrator was able to secure resources which resulted in the program
reopening as an independent living program for teen mothers and pregnant teens.
The program began accepting youth again in December 2024. Due to the
uncertainty of the program for most of 2024, the lack of staffing, and the fact the
agency did not have any cases to service, CAP implementation was difficult. The
chief administrator is aware that there is work to do, in order to come into
compliance with the areas cited in the 2023, 2024 and 2025 reviews. The chief
administrator reported they were confident in their ability to achieve compliance
with the newly designed program and increased staff.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The assessment dated 2/25/25 was reviewed and discussed on-site. The Chief
Administrator (CA) reported when the program was initially closing in March 2024,
their cases transferred to another agency. In addition, some staff moved to the
other agency as well. Therefore, Our House had to hire several new staff when
they determined the program would remain open in December 2024. The CA
reported it has been challenging to hire and train new staff, while building,
developing and opening the new program. Therefore, there were some missed
items regarding personnel files and performance evaluations. The CA plans to
have all performance evaluations completed in May 2025. While it has been
challenging, the CA indicated they believe the program is in a stable place, where
leadership feels more confident and able to handle all tasks required of them.
Financial Overview
As the agency was no providing services for most of 2024 and recently started
services, a financial audit has not yet been completed for 2024. A financial audit
was not completed in 2023. The agency’s 2024 and 2025 budgets were reviewed.
While the agency struggled financially at the beginning of 2024, the restructuring
of the program and additional resources are expected to improve financial stability.
Staff Interviews
7

One staff was interviewed on-site. Staff reported being new to the agency and
getting acclimated to the program and the new case they have been assigned.
Staff stated everything was going very well thus far. Staff stated the agency is a
very supportive and positive environment. The chief administrator is their
supervisor and has a wealth of knowledge and resources. There were no
concerns reported.
Description of Agency Walk Through
The agency remains in the same location as previous years. The building has
adequate office space for staff and meeting space for IL youth. All case files were
stored securely, and the agency maintains a cross shredder for disposal of
confidential information.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
This agency is not contracted with MDHHS to provide foster care placement or
certification services; therefore, this is not applicable.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. A corrective action plan is required.
_____________March 12, 2025________________________
Heather Reilly Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
March 13, 2025

Jessica VandenHeuvel Date
Area Manager
